content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is quick, clear and relates to basic knowledge about probability that all developers should know. It is also very quick to solve, so it fits into the clash of code spirit.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: L'Ã©noncÃ© est simple et l'exercice amusant

Hello,

I think you could also add "reverse" game mode for this clash :)

Your contribution challenges clashers mainly on two skills (except understanding) :
- rounding a float with a specified number of decimal ; a frequently encountered required skill in coc exercices' pool ; nothing more to say about it
- expectancy in statistics : a simple formula for people who know about (I suppose most of clashers), but maybe harsh for noobs ; I suggest adding a hint, and/or turning "expected value" in bold ("expected value" is the specific mathematical word for the quantity your exercise requires, but it can be read as something quite common). People who has to search about this formula may not end first of their clash, but will learn something important.

Stub generator
* Please use loopline to parse earnings and probabilities as floats.

* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Cases
* You may add some probabilities with more than 2 decimal places, so that the rounding really does something (currently there isn't any rounding really, all {expectation:.2} does is formatting the output to show 2 decimal places).

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback.
Don't you think that the parsing task is part of the problem ?
I mean it allows people to train on how to parse inputs (and that's only splitting on " " so pretty easy)
Thanks for the feedback. Does this small hint enough ?
Are the description and title removed automatically ?

Yes. This was what I had in my mind.
It should be enough to lead statistics noob clasher to search what expected value means ;)

Thank you.

I think parsing should not be the focus of a clash, unless it's a special format (i.e. not space-separated), e.g. semi-colon separated.

I see, that's updated.
I'm wondering if it could be a "shortest" clash too.

I think it could be.

And regarding the stub, I didn't expect you to change the cases too ðŸ˜… The original input format can be parsed using the "loopline" keyword, so that n earnings are read from one line, and n probabilities are read from the next line.
loopline n earning:float
loopline n probability:float

But since you've already made the changes, which are also fine, it's ok to keep it that way, and change the Input section instead:

* Please add "Two space-separated floats" after "Next N lines:".

* Please delete "as float" in the two descriptions.

Many thanks.
